#Text=Dialect used in Pudd'nhead Wilson

#Text=English Dialect , Alternative , Another and en against agin , ag'in , ag'in ' because ' ca'se going gwine , gwyne more mo ' that dat the de then den there dere , dah these dese they dey , deh this dis was ' uz with wid where whah
#Text=The above table was presented as a foundation which played into the decision to make some emendations , below , that were not authorized by Twain in 1899 .
#Text=One curious notation is that there was sometimes pronounced dere , but also dah .
#Text=Along the same lines , they most often became dey , but in one case , deh .
#Text=3. This version .
#Text=Our version is based on the 1894 publication of this novel in Hartford .
#Text=This was Twain 's original American release of the novel in book form .
#Text=A scanned copy of this book is available through Hathitrust .
#Text=The book contained some spaces in contractions : I ' ll , dat ' ll , had n't , could n't , dis ' ll , ' t ai n't / t ai n't , and dey ' ll are some examples .
#Text=These spaces were not retained in our transcription , and are not identified .
#Text=We did make a few other emendations .
#Text=These emendations were checked with the 1899 version of Pudd'nhead Wilson published by Harper & Brothers .
#Text=4. Notes on emendations .
#Text=The errors on Page 233 and Page 288 , were not changed in the 1899 book , so the case for making those changes may be found in the Detailed Notes section .
#Text=The remaining errors were corrected in the 1899 publication , presumably authorized by Twain , who essentially made the case for those emendations .
#Text=In the HTML version of this e-book , you can place your cursor over the faint silver dotted lines below the changed text to discover the original text .
#Text=The Detailed Notes section of these notes describe these emendations .
#Text=5. Other versions .

#Text=Please note that many print versions of Pudd'nhead Wilson include the phrase ' spelling and usage have been brought into conformity with modern usage , ' and editors have been liberal with their renditions of Twain 's story .
#Text=6. Detailed notes .
#Text=The Detailed Notes Section also includes issues that have come up during transcription .
#Text=One common issue is that words are sometimes split into two lines for spacing purposes in the original text .
#Text=These words are hyphenated in the physical book , but there is a question sometimes as to whether the hyphen should be retained in transcription .
#Text=The reasons behind some of these decisions are itemized .
#Text=Production Notes Section :
#Text=1. Chapter Titles .
#Text=The Chapter Titles , such as Doom in Chapter XXI . , were not part of Twain 's book .
#Text=They remain from another version of this book .
#Text=The chapter titles are used in PG 's Mark Twain index , so we have retained them .
#Text=2.
#Text=The Author 's Note .
#Text=The Author 's Note to Those Extraordinary Twins is actually the author 's introduction to the novella , Those Extraordinary Twins .
#Text=Twain originally produced this book with two parts : Pudd'nhead Wilson and Those Extraordinary Twins .
#Text=Project Gutenberg offers both stories , so we present the Author 's Note as the Introduction to Those Extraordinary Twins , as Twain intended .
#Text=If you want to read the Author 's Note , please visit the Introduction of our production of the novella , Those Extraordinary Twins .
#Text=Detailed Notes Section :
#Text=Chapter 1 .
#Text=On Page 19 , barber-shop was hyphenated between two lines for spacing .
#Text=The 1899 Harper & Brothers version used " barber shop " in this spot .
#Text=Even though barber-shop cannot be transcribed as such , the assumption is that the 1894 version put in the hyphen by mistake .
#Text=We transcribed the word barber shop .
#Text=Chapter 2 .
#Text=On Page 34 , changed ca'se to ' ca'se , used as dialect for because , in the clause : " but dat 's ca'se it 's mine .
